{"comments": {"id": 27926, "count": 26, "talk_id": 14471}, "threadId": 27926, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "14471", "description": "On any given night, more than 450,000 people in the United States are locked up in jail simply because they don't have enough money to pay bail. The sums in question are often around $500: easy for some to pay, impossible for others. This has real human consequences -- people lose jobs, homes and lives, and it drives racial disparities in the legal system. Robin Steinberg has a bold idea to change this. In this powerful talk, she outlines the plan for The Bail Project -- an unprecedented national revolving bail fund to fight mass incarceration. (This ambitious idea is part of the Audacious Project, TED's initiative to inspire and fund global change.)", "event": "TED2018", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Robin Steinberg: What if we ended the injustice of bail?", "slug": "robin_steinberg_what_if_we_ended_the_injustice_of_bail", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "3973", "slug": "robin_steinberg", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Robin", "lastname": "Steinberg", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Public defender, activist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/0898005215d52e88e5c90008c19dfd3fd5631903_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Robin Steinberg is the CEO of The Bail Project, a new organization designed to combat mass incarceration in the United States by disrupting the money bail system -- one person at a time. As she says: "I hate injustice and simply can't sit still when I see it."", "whylisten": "

Robin Steinberg is the CEO of The Bail Project and a senior fellow at the UCLA Law Criminal Justice Program. As she writes: "When I started my career, all I wanted was to be a great public defender for my clients. I vowed to fight for their rights, dignity and humanity in a system that seemed intent on crushing them, their families and their communities. It was hard work, but I woke up everyday inspired and with a sense of purpose -- even when the unfairness of the system made me cry. I was doing my part in the larger struggle for social justice -- one client at a time. But the need to do more, to rethink the very nature of public defense and challenge the larger systemic issues that fueled the cycle of criminalization and poverty led me to start The Bronx Defenders in 1997. For 20 years, I worked to create a new vision of public defense, extending legal representation and advocacy beyond criminal court with the goal of breaking that cycle. That process led to the founding of several new initiatives, including Still She Rises, a public defender office dedicated exclusively to the representation of women in the criminal justice system, and The Bronx Freedom Fund, a revolving bail fund that used philanthropic dollars to pay bail for clients who couldn’t buy their freedom.

"As it turns out, what I love most is getting people out of jail so they can be home with their families and have a fighting chance in court. My new organization, The Bail Project, will take the lessons we learned in the Bronx and go to dozens of high-need jurisdictions with the goal of paying bail for 160,000 people over the next five years, disrupting the bail system, reducing the human suffering it causes and continuing the fight to decarcerate America."

This reading and watching should make clear why it's long past time to reform America's bail system.", "rec_items": [{"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""The Bail Trap"", "blurb": "A powerful story that shows how bail decisions, often made hastily with little information, cascade to affect real lives. It also points to a startling fact: "In most jurisdictions, bail is the grease that keeps the gears of the overburdened system turning."", "note": "Nick Pinto *New York Times Magazine*, 2015", "link_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/16/magazine/the-bail-trap.html", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""Detaining the Poor: How Money Bail Perpetuates an Endless Cycle of Jail Time"", "blurb": "A study that breaks down why the population of U.S. jails is growing -- while the number of people convicted of crimes has stayed flat, the number of people held because they can’t afford bail has skyrocketed. Includes a section on why women are disproportionately affected.", "note": "Bernadette Rabuy and Daniel Kopf Prison Policy Initiative, 2016", "link_url": "https://www.prisonpolicy.org/reports/incomejails.html", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""America is Waking Up to the Injustice of Cash Bail"", "blurb": "An article that dives further into the injustice of the cash bail system, looking at how bondsmen benefit from those in tough circumstances -- and how, in cities like New Orleans, a small percentage of every bail bond contracted is kicked back to courts, sheriffs and district attorneys.", "note": "Bryce Covert *The Nation*, 2017", "link_url": "https://www.thenation.com/article/america-is-waking-up-to-the-injustice-of-cash-bail/", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""Racial and Ethnic Disparity in Pretrial Criminal Processing"", "blurb": "A classic study that shows how stereotypes influence criminal processing, with unthinkably unfair outcomes for Black and Latino defendants.", "note": "Traci Schlesinger *Justice Quarterly*, 2005", "link_url": "https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/07418820500088929?journalCode=rjqy20&", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}, {"title": "Film", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "WATCH", "headline": "*Ramel's Story: The Bail Project*", "blurb": "Ramel Edwards is a Bronx native who fell into the bail trap when he was arrested for riding his bike on the sidewalk. His story is so powerful, it inspired this short film -- and a mention in my talk. "robin_steinberg", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Robin", "lastname": "Steinberg", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Public defender, activist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/0898005215d52e88e5c90008c19dfd3fd5631903_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Robin Steinberg is the CEO of The Bail Project, a new organization designed to combat mass incarceration in the United States by disrupting the money bail system -- one person at a time. As she says: "I hate injustice and simply can't sit still when I see it."", "whylisten": "

Robin Steinberg is the CEO of The Bail Project and a senior fellow at the UCLA Law Criminal Justice Program. As she writes: "When I started my career, all I wanted was to be a great public defender for my clients. I vowed to fight for their rights, dignity and humanity in a system that seemed intent on crushing them, their families and their communities. It was hard work, but I woke up everyday inspired and with a sense of purpose -- even when the unfairness of the system made me cry. I was doing my part in the larger struggle for social justice -- one client at a time. But the need to do more, to rethink the very nature of public defense and challenge the larger systemic issues that fueled the cycle of criminalization and poverty led me to start The Bronx Defenders in 1997. For 20 years, I worked to create a new vision of public defense, extending legal representation and advocacy beyond criminal court with the goal of breaking that cycle. That process led to the founding of several new initiatives, including Still She Rises, a public defender office dedicated exclusively to the representation of women in the criminal justice system, and The Bronx Freedom Fund, a revolving bail fund that used philanthropic dollars to pay bail for clients who couldn’t buy their freedom.

"As it turns out, what I love most is getting people out of jail so they can be home with their families and have a fighting chance in court. My new organization, The Bail Project, will take the lessons we learned in the Bronx and go to dozens of high-need jurisdictions with the goal of paying bail for 160,000 people over the next five years, disrupting the bail system, reducing the human suffering it causes and continuing the fight to decarcerate America."

author: Robin_Steinberg;
title: What if we ended the injustice of bail?

aws-transcripts.transcript: I will never forget. The first time I visited the client in jail, the heavy metal door slammed behind me and I heard the key turn in the lock. The cement floor underneath me had a sticky film on it that made a ripping sound like Kate being pulled off a box every time I moved on my foot. The only connection to the outside world was a small window place too high to see. There was a small square table bolted to the floor and two metal chairs, one on either side. That was the first time I understood viscerally, just for a fleeting moment what incarceration might feel like. And I promised myself all those years ago was a young public defender that I would never, ever forget. That feeling and I never have it inspired me to fight for each and every one of my client's freedom, as if it was my own freedom. Ah, concept so fundamental to the American psyche that it is enshrined in our Constitution. And yet America is addicted to imprisonment from slavery through mass incarceration. It always has been. Look, we all know the shocking numbers. The United States incarcerates more people per capita than almost any nation on the planet. But what you may not know is that on any given night in America, almost half 1,000,000 people go to sleep in those concrete jail cells who have not been convicted off anything. These mothers and fathers and sons and daughters are there for one reason and one reason only. They cannot afford to pay the price of their freedom, and that price is called bail. Now Bale was actually created as a form of conditional release. The theory was simple. Set bail in an amount that somebody could afford to pay. They would pay it. It would give them an incentive to come back to court. It would give them some skin In the game. Bill was never intended to be used as punishment. Bail was never intended to hold people in jail cells and bail was never ever intended to create a two tier system of justice, one for the rich and one for everybody else. But that is precisely what it is done. 75% of people in American local jails are there because they cannot pay bail. I demand to know why he was being stopped. Let's talk for a moment about what it means to be in jail, even for a few days. Well, it could mean losing your job losing your home, jeopardizing her immigration status. It may even mean losing custody of your children. Ah, third of sexual victimization by jail staff happens in the first few days in jail, and almost half of all jail deaths, including suicides, happened in that first week. What's more, if your health in jail on bail, you're four times more likely to get a jail sentence than if you had been free. And that jail sentence will be three times longer. And if you're black or Latino and cash bail has been set, you are two times more likely to remain stuck in that jail cell than if you were white. Jail in America is a terrifying, dehumanizing and violent experience. Now imagine for just one moment that it's you stuck in that jail cell and you don't have the $500 to get out and someone comes along and offers you a way out. Just plead guilty. They say you could go home back to your job, just plead guilty. You can kiss your kids good night tonight, so you do what anybody would do in that situation. You plead guilty whether you did it or not, but now you have a criminal record that's going to follow you for the rest of your life, jailing people because they don't have enough money to pay. Bail is one of the most unfair. Immoral things we do is a society, but it is also expensive and counterproductive American taxpayers. They spend $14,000,000,000 annually holding people in jail cells who haven't been convicted of anything. That's $40,000,000 a day. What's perhaps more confounding is it doesn't make us any safer. I have been a public defender for over half my life, and I have stood by and watched thousands of clients as they were dragged into those jail cells because they didn't have enough money to pay bail. I am watched as questions of justice were subsumed by questions of money, calling into question the legitimacy of the entire American legal system. And in that unexpected moment, the idea for the Bronx Freedom Fund was born. Look, we didn't know what to expect. Our ideas of why people come back to court and how the criminal legal system itself is operated. Turns out money isn't what makes people come back to court. We know this because when the Bronx Freedom Fund pays bail, 96% of clients return for every court appearance, laying waste to the myth that it's money that matter. It's powerful evidence that we don't need cash or ankle bracelets or unnecessary systems of surveillance and supervision.
